none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, September 29, 1877
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from W. A. Alexander, September 29, 1877
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 18 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Princeton Seminary Sep 29 1877.

L. L. McInnis,
        Dear Mc        Your letter has been clamoring
for a speedy reply from me for over a week, but I have been
in the midst of most pressing duties, and snatch a few
moments late Sat. night, in which to recollect an
old & esteemed friend. Having just blacked my
Sunday boots and being unable to decide between several
books before me, I reject all & compromise on my
pen. I am still as hard a student as when at
College, usually pulling out my lamp about
last, at night. I, however do not bother to cram & bother
for recitation, I am not seeking a reputation for prompt
recitations &c. but I find that with extended & varied study
my thirst for knowledge grows on me, and I keep books
of parallel study piled up at my side, which sometimes
crowd out my text book. I am growing hump shouldered
& nearsighted & use a pair of eye glasses for seeing objects
distinctly when remote, as the blackboard &c (nose grabbers)
I have just written and am committing on a sermon
for next week on the Resurrection of Christ.

**A Deep Dive into a Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's break this down. First, I'm looking at what appears to be a handwritten letter, and I want a precise transcription. The header reads "Princeton Seminary Sep 29 1877." Then, the salutation is "L. L. McInnis," followed by "Dear M", and then a superscript squiggle. Given that it's addressed to McInnis and the informality of the tone later, I'll go with "Dear M<sup>c</sup>" as if it's a nickname.

The first line reads: "Your letter has been clamoring," which suggests that the writer has been meaning to respond. He continues to mention the constraints and difficulty with finding time. The writer mentions he's been caught up in his duties for over a week, and he snatches a few moments late on a Saturday night. It looks like he's going to recollect an old and esteemed friend. He's just finished blacking his Sunday boots. He finds himself unable to choose between several books and so decides to write. He's still as much a student as he was in college.

He goes on to say he's pulling out his lamp at night, but admits he doesn't "bother to cram & bother" for recitation. It's a bit odd to have the same word repeated. Perhaps it's a repetition? I'll transcribe what I see. It seems he's not after a reputation for prompt recitations. He then goes on to say that his thirst for knowledge continues to increase, and that he keeps books of parallel study piled up. He finds these books sometimes crowd out his textbook. He also mentions he's becoming hunch-shouldered and nearsighted, so he uses glasses. He uses the phrase "nose grabbers" which is old-timey slang for glasses.

He then tells us that he has just written and is "committing on a sermon" for the next week, which is on the Resurrection of Christ. "Committing on" is the phrase that's written, even though the modern phrasing is a bit different. I'm going to maintain the exact wording, especially on those more interesting phrases!

I dont believe I have written you since I left
Maryland. I came up by bay to Balto by the
same steamer, & same moonlight, with the same
sentimental feelings I mentioned before, In fact,
I (being past 16.) have reached a critical & sentimental
period, & there never was a fellow as bad off for
a sweet heart to love him, or so lonely and emptied
in the felt sense of his need as I am at this
present time. If I dont fall head over heels in love as
soon as I get among the Southern women, it will because
they are none worthy, which presumption however is a
self evident falsehood. Cant you console me any. I dont
know anybody I want. My Xanthippe my ideal – bless her – I've
never yet seen. Recommendations from you will
be respectfully heeded. I spent, to resume my narration
3 days in Balto with a friend from Charleston, whom I
had met here. – now preaching in Balto. We went together to
the Insane Asylum (this old Ballie never predicted of me) the
Park, Johns Hopkins Univ., Balto. City College &c & I enjoyed
my time very much. Our drive in the park was magnificent
We called on some girls, but they couldnt talk about anything
but watering places & novels, on both which topics my gab
at best can be but limited, – & on the whole, though
they were rich. I concluded they didnt suit me (God
[Margin: didn't like them a bit.]

**My Transcription and Interpretation of this Handwritten Letter** As an expert, I've approached this task as one would a delicate archaeological dig, painstakingly unearthing the writer's thoughts and intentions from the very ink. Here's my transcription, capturing the essence of the writer's sentiments and conveying the nuances of his word choices:

I dont believe I have written you since I left
Maryland. I came up by bay to Balto by the
same steamer, & same moonlight, with the same
sentimental feelings I mentioned before, In fact,
I (being past 16) have reached a critical & sentimental
period, & there never was a fellow as bad off for
a sweet heart to love him, or so lonely and emptied
in the felt sense of his need as I am at this
present time. If I dont fall head over heels in love as
soon as I get among the Southern women, it will because
they are none worthy, which presumption however is a
self evident falsehood. Cant you console me any. I dont
know anybody I want. My Xanthippe my ideal – bless her – I've
never yet seen. Recommendations from you will
be respectfully heeded. I spent, to resume my narration
3 days in Balto with a friend from Charleston, whom I
had met here. – now preaching in Balto. We went together to
the Insane Asylum (this old Ballie never predicted of me) the
Park, Johns Hopkins Univ., Balto. City College &c & I enjoyed
my time very much. Our drive in the park was magnificent
We called on some girls, but they couldnt talk about anything
but watering places & novels, on both which topics my gab
at best can be but limited, – & on the whole, though
they were rich. I concluded they didnt suit me (God [Margin: didn't like them a bit.]

The handwriting is a lovely cursive, characteristic of the late 19th or early 20th century, with a slight slant. I can see a clear yearning in the writer's words. He’s left Maryland and is now in Baltimore ("Balto"), reminiscing about the journey and the emotions it evoked. There’s a distinct thread of melancholy, a feeling of being in a "critical and sentimental period". The writer is looking for a sweetheart and feels alone without one. He seems to be joking or self-deprecating by stating he's "past 16", especially in the context of feeling the need for a "sweet heart". The letter is one single block of text with marginalia. The writer's thoughts are flowing, and it’s evident that he is confiding in the recipient, whom he addresses as "Ballie". He describes a visit to Baltimore with a friend from Charleston. He mentions going to the Insane Asylum with "Ballie", which implies a shared past or history. He critiques the women he encountered during his visit, as they were not deep enough for him. The crossed-out word "Xanthippe" and the interlinear insertion "my ideal" is the key to his state of mind. Xanthippe was known for being ill-tempered (Socrates' wife). The writer immediately replaces it with "my ideal," suggesting a search for a more perfect love. I have placed the marginalia – "didn't like them a bit" – in the context of his thoughts about the women he met. It flows naturally from the last line: he didn't like them and the tone implies it was "God" who didn't like them. I considered alternative readings of a possibly inelegant ending, but the vertical text works better as a final, humorous aside.

We have about the No of boys here as last year. A bro. of Creigh-
ton's is here. He lived in Tenn a few years and has become
completely southernized. There is a bare possibility that
A. E. may be here with us this term also. We have
5 Welchmen in Sem'y Canadians Nova Scotians.
Southern Western Eastern (no New Englanders) boys.
Pres. United Pres. Dutch Reformed, Methodist, Lutheran
&c all in our Seminary. I met a Mississippian at
the College. Clark (Fresh) of Coahoma, a friend of
Pages, & nephew of "Windy Jim, he of Sweet Coahoma
by the river side" (Alcorn) He is a nice fellow & is
a Virginia Z. X. He says Page is going to Ox,
to study law, - as is also J. C. Foster. Gen Stewart
& Sullivan are after Charlton to apply for a
new tutorship which will likely be formed this fall.
Charlton is now Cashier of a Kosciusko bank.
My sister Blanche has gone to College near Louisville
Ky. My Bro. Wm Hadden was severely burnt by
the explosion of his lamp a few weeks ago. over his
back & is laid up for several weeks. - a fearful
accident - with a narrow escape. Katy, Carlton
Preached - (I apologize for the capital P.) in Kosciusko
recently. Sam Towel is married. I never hear

**Analyzing and Transcribing a Handwritten Document**

Okay, so I've got this handwritten document in front of me, probably a letter. The handwriting is a bit hurried, but I can make most of it out. It looks like it's about college or seminary life, with names of people, places, and events. Time to get to work.

First, I'll go line by line, carefully transcribing the text. There are a few things to watch out for, like those older cursive styles and some abbreviations. Let's see... the first line mentions "No" with a superscript "o." I'll transcribe that accurately.  "Creigh-ton's" is clear, and "Tenn" is Tennessee. I need to figure out what that word is before "possibility". It could be "bore" or "base". But reading it, "bare possibility" is the likely idiom, even though the 'a' looks like an 'o'.  Hmm, "A. E." or "A. Es"? Let's stick with "A. E." for now; could be initials.  "Sem'y" means Seminary. Then there's a list of boys from different places: Southern, Western, Eastern (no New Englanders). Then some religious denominations in the seminary. "Missippian" is a bit scrawled, let's keep that in mind, I need to see if it's correct. "Clark (Fresh)" implies Freshman. "Windy Jim" is quoted; that's a reference to a person.  That word in the parentheses by the river - it could be "Neom" or "Deom" or "Ucom". Wait, based on context, it must be (Alcorn) because it's a quote.  The next line has "a Virginia Z. X.". Is that "Zeta Chi"? It looks like a Z and an X. Maybe that's what it is, and I should transcribe the glyph as is. Or maybe it's just a guy's initials?  Going to Oxford, so I'll put "Ox," to study law, with "J. C. Foster". "Gen Stewart & Sullivan" are after "Charlton" to get him to tutor. The name "Charlton" appears again later as "Cashier of a Kosciusko bank." I see "Blanche" going to college. Then "My Bro. Wm Hadden" (that's his name, I should be able to spell it correctly). A burn from a lamp explosion, "a few weeks ago". Oh, poor guy, laid up for weeks. And a "fearful accident". Here's the most tricky sentence "Katy, Carlton Preached". Is it "Katy" preaching, or is this the person "Katy" being addressed?  And, wait, there's a capital 'P', let's see why, the apology... it refers to the start of "Preached". This is a tricky word, it's missing the letter 'h'. There is no "h" in "Preached", so I am going to keep the capital 'P'.  And "Sam Towel is married", recently. All good!

So, the first pass is done. Let's make it look polished. I'll double-check some of those tricky words and fix any mistakes I might have made and double check the capitalization. I will also make some minor fixes, like the superscript on "No". I should also make sure all the punctuation is correct.  Hmm, is it "bare possibility" or "bore possibility"? It's "bare". I should add the "r" to "Sam Towel". Is the text "Missippian"? or "Mississippian"? It's "Missippian" [sic]. Is there a missing "s" from a word "Pages,"? It's "Page's" in the original text, but not quite... there is some writing at the top - an incomplete letter, which makes it "Pages,". Or maybe "Pages,". I'll check "Alcorn". It's a key name. Let's stick with "Alcorn" because the quotation mentions that person. The person's name, "Alcorn" is clear. It's "Z. X." - or "Sigma Chi". Okay, I should transcribe as is, for the symbol. "Wm Hadden". That's a key name. Ah, yes, "My Bro. Wm Hadden". That's the correct name. Hmm, is it "Charlton" or "Carlton" (line 21)? The original text is "Carlton". If the name is "Katy Carlton," or "Katy, Carlton". The context suggests a vocative, so there is the comma. I'll make sure the text has

from the Ox. girls. Bigger keeps quiet about them. I
hope they florish, even as a green bay horse. Tell them
so for me, will you, when you write, giving them my
love.

            My work here is chiefly in Theology proper
and Church history. In Theology our teacher Dr
A. A. Hodge, a jolly fat fellow – is the best teacher
I was ever under & makes the study one perpetual
feast, and one perpetual strain of work. We
are grappling with such preliminary questions as
Inspirations, the absurdity of the Romish doctrines
of an infallible church, infallible Pope and
of revelation handed down by tradition, Rationalism
Quakerism, Deism &c. the proper function of
the reason & of the feelings in religion. Next week
we begin the subject itself. What is God, what is
or can be known of him, & what, by nature & revelation
do we know of him &c             In Church history
we have gotten down as far as the time when
Jerusalem Rome was destroyed & Peter didnt found the
Church of Rome & wasnt Pope. In gospel history
we are on the birth of Xt, circumstances
preceding & succeeding, &c after having

I'm operating as a professional transcriptionist, so accuracy and adherence to specific guidelines are paramount. The instructions are clear: read top-to-bottom, maintain the original layout, and be mindful of the quirks of the handwriting. I’ve also got to interpret the handwriting correctly, which means dealing with those slightly slanted, cursive letters. I'm going to leverage my IIIF experience with some specific HTML tags, including `a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, and `sup`, to make sure this meets those standards. I will also be using Markdown tables for any data transcription if needed, although I don't see that here yet. First, I looked over the image, which appears to be a page from a letter. I immediately see this is about academic studies, specifically Theology and Church History. The mentions of "Ox. girls" (Oxford?), "Bigger," and "Dr. A. A. Hodge" (Archibald Alexander Hodge, Princeton Theological Seminary), suggest a late 19th-century context. And there's a correction near the bottom: "Rome" is struck through and "Jerusalem" is written above it. Now, it's time to transcribe, line by line. I’m thinking through each word, ensuring I understand it, and then I’m going to consider formatting. I’ll keep the original spelling and punctuation, even when it’s unconventional. For example, I see the word "florish" (spelled without a 'u'), but I will transcribe it this way since that's what's written. There's also a mention of a "green bay horse." Now, the idiom is "green bay tree". "Horse" does seem to be the actual letters on the page. I'll stick with that, as it could be a deliberate error or an inside joke. I’m also making sure to preserve line breaks with `
` and start new paragraphs with `

`. There are a few instances of "&" which will be preserved, and "Xt" for Christ and "&c" for etc. I need to handle corrections, too. Because I can't use `` or `` tags, I need to represent the correction of "Rome" being crossed out and "Jerusalem" written above. I am going to have to use `Jerusalem Rome` to denote a supralinear insertion, which visually represents what's going on, but lacks proper strike through. It's the best I can do within the IIIF framework and given the constraints. I’m also checking for any typos. I will transcribe what’s actually on the page, and the final look should be faithful to the image. With the careful attention to detail, I will now craft the final output. The main goal is to reproduce the image accurately and present it in a readable format.

But are its teachings radically
contradictory to ultimate laws
- incredible to our minds which
are made in a way that some
things are impossible to it. Reason
tells us that 1 cant be 3. nor 3 be 1,
+ no revelation, however powerfully
attested, cant commend itself to
my credence which teaches me
that 1 is 3. unless the ultimate
laws of my mind be radically
changed, so that what is now
to me clearly impossible, becomes
possible. (E.g.) If the Bible taught
that one God is a trinity of 3 Gods
no external evidence could
rationally make me believe it-
But. where it says that God is
one in one way or direction, & 3 in
another direction or sense, I can
believe it if the Revelation be
sufficiently adduced by evidence; for
then it no longer is contradictory to
my mind, but simply incompreh
-sible, & I find that I can [crossed out: myself believing]
the incomprehensible. + that I do belie
the incomprehensible every day in the outside world

**Analyzing and Transcribing a Handwritten Theological Text** Right, here we go. I've got this image of a handwritten document in English. The handwriting is a bit hurried, cursive, but generally legible – nothing too tricky here. There are a few strikeouts and insertions, which is always interesting. The content seems to be about theology, specifically the Trinity, reason, and revelation. My first step will be to transcribe it line by line and preserve the layout as much as possible, including those strikeouts and insertions. So, the first line… Okay, it starts with, "But are its teachings radically..." and I need to keep it as it appears. Then I move on to "contradictory to ultimate laws", and so on. Now, this is where it gets interesting: the writer is really grappling with the tension between reason and revelation, which will affect the transcription. I'm transcribing: "But are its teachings radically contradictory to ultimate laws". And it's not clear on whether it's "it's" or "its". Let's put down what it shows: "its". Now for the next line: "- incredible to our minds which are made in a way that some things are impossible to it". This is crucial to grasp. Reason, he is saying, imposes limits. The next is "Reason tells us that 1 cant be 3. nor 3 be 1," and, "no revelation, however powerfully attested, cant commend itself to my credence". Then comes, "which teaches me that 1 is 3. unless the ultimate laws of my mind be radically changed." This is the core issue! I'm just going to type it. The next bit is like an example. The writer goes on: "so that what is now to me clearly impossible, becomes possible. (E.g.) If the Bible taught that one God is a trinity of 3 Gods, no external evidence could rationally make me believe it-". It's a nice sentence, I want to transcribe it correctly. Then comes the central argument: "But. where it says that God is one in one way or direction, & 3 in another direction or sense, I can believe it if the Revelation be sufficiently adduced by evidence;". For some reason, the word "says" is underlined. I'll include the italics. Then, it continues: "for then it no longer is contradictory to my mind, but simply incompreh-sible,". Now it comes to the trickier bit. Now here, I have to figure out the intended sentence, so I'll write everything. I find that I can, and here's a strikethrough: [crossed out: myself believing]. It ends with the line "the incomprehensible." And now comes the final bit: "+ that I do belie" the final bit: "the incomprehensible every day in the outside world." The final sentence is a kind of culmination. And the strikeout. It seems the writer is saying that while the doctrine of the Trinity seems to contradict reason, we can still believe it because we find that it isn't contradictory to us. Okay, I think I've got it. Time to format this accurately. I'll preserve the layout and those pesky strike-throughs and insertions, and it's done.

So, my reason is 1st a presup
-posed basis to my reception of
a revelation from God of my duty
to him. 2nd my reason, while it
is not to understand or to prove
the revealed contents, yet is to
judge whether I do my nature
violence in believing it on Gods
testimony. 3rdly Reason
is to judge of the evidence of the
Revelation to decide whether what
purports to come from God, has
evidences of divinity upon it. This
3rd function of reason we exercised
under Stewart, in our "Ev of Xtianty"
Then, what we see to be a credible revelation,
we are bound to
receive & we will be held responsible
under it. Reason has the further
function, in the
worship &c of determining how the Scripture
injunction "Let all things be done
decently & in order" shall be carried
out, & it was this – practical exercise
under a received Revelation – that you
alluded to in your letter about Meth-
-odist overdoings at meetings
Pardon me for this metaphysical
tangential turn I took. It came

**A Summary of My Transcription Process**

Okay, so I've been given this handwritten text and my job is to produce a transcription, right? First, I need to understand what I'm looking at. It seems like an old letter or note, written in cursive, probably from the 19th or early 20th century. It's in English, thankfully, and looks like it's broken down into points. I have to read this text line by line and start typing.

I need to get it right. I have to go through each line, carefully, and accurately reproduce every word, including all the punctuation, spacing, and line breaks. Okay, the first step is to get the words right. This 1<sup>st</sup> word is ambiguous. Is it 1a, 1st? Given the other numbers, it is “1<sup>st</sup>”.

There are a few things to watch out for – superscript numbers and abbreviations. I'm noting the abbreviations and the common names like "Stewart". I'm also looking out for crossed-out words. I am noticing deletions. My instructions are clear: *Transcribe all text*. Hmm, what about crossed-out text?

I have no tools to show the deletion – I cannot use `<s>` or `<del>`. I should just include the text. But the prompt says not to, so I can't write `[deleted]`.

I must omit any text that is crossed out. But what if it's unclear? Then the reader can fill in the gaps. In line 14, I wasn't sure if the word "reason" was crossed out. It made the sentence unclear. I must be precise and stick to the original, so the reader can see what the person wrote. I am keeping "reason" as I interpret it as potentially a formatting artifact. I will be extra careful. The phrase "practical exercise of" is clearly struck.

Okay, so, let’s go through it one more time, and I need to double-check everything. I must make sure that it's all in the right order and that I'm not missing anything. Especially the line breaks.

Now I am ready to output the text with the correct formatting, putting things in the correct HTML tags. So, there it is! I've done it. A transcription of the text, ready for whatever it's needed for. It's simple, but I hope this works. Now I'm done.

studied as questions of date, the
birth of Xt, his baptism & Crucifixion,
& the length of his ministry. I beg your
pardon if I am running off into a technical
train, I simply mentioned these to let you
know what kind of topics are absorbing our
attention. In addition to these we have
Hebrew in Psalms, lectures on Pentateuch
on Church Government, & Apologetics.
I lead off, as I said, in the opening sermon
of the campaign next week.

Prof. Bobbie not only answered in a
nice, truly Christian letter to mine, on
little Robbie, but also sent me our little
boy's photograph which is perfectly beautiful

My experience peddling, as was
the business called [illegible] several times
this summer, was in a great
many respects pleasant, & in others
difficult & tiresome. It showed me
the sterner, more unpolished state
of life & gave me a practical realiz-
ation of what a high privalige it
is to be an intelligent, educated man,
whose mind can rise higher than
the daily rote of search for meat & bread
& contemplate more intellectual subjects
I became forcibly convinced that
we are as Dr. Stewart said of us.
picked men, picked & marked from
the many by a peculiar attainment,
education.

**Ready to Transcribe**

I have to interpret this handwriting, maintain the layout, and I've got to use these specific HTML tags: `a`, `b`, `br`, `i`, `img`, `p`, `small`, `span`, `sub`, `sup`. No commentary, just the transcribed text, and no matter how tempted I am to guess, I've got to stick to what the text *says*.

Now, analyzing the image itself, it looks like a handwritten letter, probably from the late 19th or early 20th century. The script is cursive and quick, but generally legible. It seems to be discussing some theological studies - topics like baptism, the Crucifixion, Hebrew, and the Pentateuch. There's also some personal correspondence ("Prof. Bobbie") and an account of a summer experience involving "peddling."

So, starting line by line, here’s how I’m approaching this: I need to preserve the layout. I am noting my deliberations on the specific nuances of the handwriting. For instance, "Xt" is almost certainly "Christ". I've got to remember to keep the ampersand as is. I have to interpret abbreviations correctly. It's a matter of looking at each word and making sure it fits the context. I’m making careful distinctions such as the difference between "technical" and "technical" as well as between "topics" and "topies". It’s these types of subtle distinctions that are critical in transcription work. Then, I need to look for patterns to decipher abbreviations, like the "Dr." before "Stewart". However I hated to be the object of so
much a priori misunderstanding among
the people. For some thought me a vender
of just any books, - & would call for "Moody"
or "Night Scenes" Hymn books, some thought
that I disseminated patent medicine,
some spectacles, some that I was a
tramp, some, an impostor, some that I
was tax assessor & collector, some, to
cap the climax, that I was an itinerant
vaccinator. These views of course
I would at once dispel. but the sight
of this me approaching, usually sug-
-gested some such theory to account
for a man with pack approaching,
- nay, more perhaps, if it had only been
disclosed. Some suspected that I
"followed preaching": I must be
assuming a clerical look, as a stranger
in Balt. said he knew from my looks
I was a clergyman

Bingham is clerk in a drug store
at Moss Point Miss Jackson Co.
Write to him, & I assure you he
will appreciate it. He is bad
off to assume matrimonial &c,
But it may be as it is with me
that he finds himself more willing
than the other half of the Universe
He thinks of getting rich, buying
the proprietor out & staying there

**The Transcription Process: A Deep Dive** Alright, let's break this down. First, I see the task: transcribe this handwritten text while adhering to some strict rules about accuracy and allowed HTML tags. I'm going to have to be meticulous here. The content seems to be a handwritten letter, maybe from the late 1800s or early 1900s, given the style and content. The handwriting is cursive, somewhat free-flowing, but generally decipherable. I see a single column of text with a clear paragraph break. Now, it's time to dig into the text line by line. I'm focusing on preserving the original words, spelling, and punctuation. I'll need to interpret the handwriting, making sure to avoid injecting my own assumptions. "However I hated..." - that's pretty clear. "a priori misunderstanding" - Okay, I'll transcribe "a priori" as is, even if it's italicized by convention, since italics aren't allowed. It looks like the writer used plain text. "vender" - an older spelling, noted. "Moody" and "Night Scenes" are in quotes, so those have to be preserved. "Patent medicine" and the other things mentioned give some insight into the writer's world and perception by others. The person seems to be facing many stereotypes. "Impostor" - I'll double-check this later to make sure it's correct. "Itinerant vaccinator" - that's a key bit of context. "Balt." likely means Baltimore, and "Miss" likely means Mississippi. There's a shift in the second paragraph. "Bingham is clerk..." I see a new topic and a new voice, so I'll make sure to create a new paragraph. "Moss Point Miss Jackson Co." - I'll preserve the abbreviations. And of course, the "&c" at the end. It is shorthand for et cetera. I'll have to keep "Universe" capitalized as it seems to be important in the text. I'm keeping an eye out for any implied italics or emphasis but won't interpret, and I'll only transcribe. Princeton Seminary Sep. 29, 1877.

L. L. McInnis
     Dear Mc                         Your letter has been clamoring for a speedy reply from
me for over a week, but I have been in the midst of most pressing duties, and
snatch a few moments lat Sat. night in which to recollect an old & esteemed
friend. Having just blacked my Sunday boots and being unable to decide between
several books before me, I reject all & compromise on m y pen. I am still as
hard a student as when at College, usually putting out my lamp about last, at
night. I, however do not bother to cram & bother for recitation. I am not
seeking a reputation for prompt recitations etc. but I find that with extended
& varied study my thirst for knowledge grows on me, and I keep books of parallel
study piled up at my side, which sometimes crowd out my textbook. I am gxxxxxg
growing hump shouldered & nearsighted & use a pair of eye glasses for seeing objects
distinctly. When remote, as the blackboard etc (nose grabbers).

     I have just written and am committing on a sermon for next week on the
Resurrection of Christ.

     I don't believe I have written you since I left Maryland. I came up by
ferry to Balto. by the same steamer, & same moonlight with the same sentimental
feelings I mentioned before. In fact, I (being past 16), have reached a critical
& sentimental period. & there never was a fellow as bad off for a sweetheart
to love him or so lonely and emptied in the felt-sense of his need as I am at
this present time. If I don't fall headover heels in love as soon as I get among
the Southern women, it will because they are none worthy which presumption however
is a self evident falsehood. Can't you console me any. I don't know anybody
I want. My Xanthippi, my ideal, bless her - I've never yet seen.

Recommendations from you will be respectfully heeded. I spent, to resume
my narrative 3 days in Balt. with a friend from Charleston who I had met here.
Now xx preaching in Balto. We went together to the Insane Asylum (this old
Ballie never predicted of me,) the part, John Hopkins Univ. Balto City College
etc, & I enjoyed my time very much. One drive in the park was magnificent.
We called on some girls, but they couldn't talk about anything but watering
places & novels, on both which topics my gab at best can be but limited, - &
on the whole though they were rich I concluded they didn't suit me. So I didn't
tell them anything soft.

We have about the no of boys here as last year. A bro/ther/ of Creighton's
is here. He lived in Tenn. a few years and has become completely southernized.
There's a bare possibility that A. E. may be here with us this term also. We
have 5 Welchmen in Sem'y Canadians Nova Scotians, Southern Western Eastern
(No New Englanders) boys. Pres. United Pres. Dutch Reformed, Methodist, Lutheran
etc all in our Seminary. I met a Mississippian at the College. Clark (Fresh.)
of Coahoma, a friend of Page's & nephew of "Windy Jim, he of Sweet Coahoma by
the riverside" (Alcom) He is a nice fellow & is a Virginia S.X. He says Page
is going to Ox/ford/ to study law - as is also J. C. Foster. Gen. Stewart &
Sullivan are after Charlton to apply for a new tutorship which will likely be
formed this fall. Charlton is now Cashier of a Koscuisko bank. My sister Blanche
has gone to college near Louisville, Ky. My Bro. Mr. Hadden was severely burnt
by the explosion of his lamp a few weeks ago over his back & is laid up for
several weeks, - a fearful accident - with a narrow escape.

Katy Carlton Preached - (I apologize for the Capitol P.) in Koscuisdo recently.
Sam Newel is married. I never hear from the Ox/ford/ girls. Bigger keeps quiet

about them. I hope they florish, even as a green bay horse. Tell them so for

My work here is chiefly in Theology proper and church history. In theology
our teacher Dr. A. A. Hodge, a jolly fat-fellow- is the best teacher I was ever
under & makes the study one perpetual feast, and one perpetual strain of work.
We are grappling with such preliminary questions as Inspirations, the absurdity
of the Romish doctrines of an infallible church, infallible Pope and of revelation
handed down by tradition. Rationalism Quakerism, Diesm etc the Proper function
of the reason & of the feelings in religion. Next week we begin the subject-
itself. What is God, What is or can be known of him, & what, by nature & revela-
tion do we know of him etc. In Church history we have gotten down as far as the
time when XXXXXXXXXX Rome- Jerusalem was destroyed & Peter didn't found the
church of Rome & wasn't Pope. In gospel history we are on the birth of Xt.
Cirsumstances preceding & succeeding etc after having studied as questions of
date. The birth of Xt his baptism & Crucifixion & the length of his ministry.
I beg your pardon, if I am running off into a technical train, I simply mention-
ed these to let you know what kind of topics are absorbing our attention. In
addition to these we have Hebrew in Psalmes, lectures on Pentateuch, on Church
Government, & apologetics. I head off, as I said, in the opening sermon of the
campaign next week.

Prof. Bobbie not only answered in a nice, truly Christian letter to mine
on little Robbie but - also sent me our little boy's photograph which is perfectly
beautiful.

My experience piddling, as was the business called to me several times

    Prof. Bobbie not only answered in a nice, truly Christian letter to mine
on little Robbie but - also sent me our little boy's photograph which is perfectly
beautiful.

    My experience piddling, as was the business called to me several times

this summer, was in a great many respects pleasant, & in others difficult &
tiresome. It showed me the sterner, more unpolished state of life & gave me
a practical realization of what a high privalege it is to be an intelligent-
educated man. Whose mind can rise higher than the daily rote of search XX
for meat and bread & contemplete more intellectual subjects. I became forcibly
convinced that we are, as Sen. Stewart said of us, picked men. picked & markedXXXXXX from
the many by a attainment, education. However, I hated to be the object
of so much a priori misunderstanding among the people. For some thought me a ven-
dor of just any books - & would call for "Moody" or "Night Scenes" Hymn books. Some
thought that I disseminated patent medicine. Some spectacles, some that I was
a tramp, some, an impostor, some that I was tax assesser & collector, some, to
cap the climax, that I was an itenerant vaccinator. These views of course I
would at once dispel, but the sight of this me approaching usually suggested some
such theory to account for a man with pack approaching, nay, more perhaps, if it
had only been disclosed. Some suspected that I "followed preaching." I must be
assuming a clerical look, as a stranger in Balt. said he knew from my looks I was
a clergyman.

Bingham is clerk in a drug store at Moss Point, Miss., Jackson Co. Write
to him & I assure you he will appreciate it. He is bad off to assume matrimon-
ial etc. But it may be as it is with me that he finds himself more willing than
the other half of the Universe. He thinks of getting rich, buying the proprietor
out & staying there forever.

has entered into partnership with Wills at XX Raymon & seriously
thinks of doing the same with W's sister in law.

I am afraid that Hays missed the mark in taking up the law. He is not cut
out for it. I told him I hoped him much success at the bar but that I would
